Min-Max Range Standardization

Source: R/standardization.R
standardize_range.Rd

**L1 Internal Helper.** Rescales a numeric vector to a specified range, typically [0, 1]. Preserves the original distribution shape while compressing to new bounds.

Usage

standardize_range(x, new_min = 0, new_max = 1, na.rm = TRUE)

Arguments

x

Numeric vector to standardize

new_min

Numeric. Minimum of new scale (default 0)

new_max

Numeric. Maximum of new scale (default 1)

na.rm

Logical. Should missing values be removed? Default TRUE.

Value

List containing:

  • standardized: Numeric vector rescaled to [new_min, new_max]

  • meta: List with:

    • method: "range"

    • original_min: Minimum before standardization

    • original_max: Maximum before standardization

    • new_min: Target minimum

    • new_max: Target maximum

    • n_valid: Number of non-missing values

    • n_missing: Number of missing values

Details

**Formula:** x_new = ((x - min(x)) / (max(x) - min(x))) * (new_max - new_min) + new_min

**What this produces:** - Minimum value → new_min - Maximum value → new_max - All other values linearly rescaled between - Preserves relative ordering and distribution shape

**Common uses:** - Rescale to [0, 1]: useful for proportions, probabilities - Rescale to [1, 7]: convert different scales to common Likert scale - Rescale to [0, 100]: convert to percentage-like scale

**When to use vs. z-scores:** - Use range standardization when you want bounded output (e.g., [0,1]) - Use z-scores when you want to preserve variance information - Both are defensible; choice depends on research goals

**Peer review justification:** Min-max standardization is standard practice when combining variables into composites. It's intuitive (everyone understands a 0-1 scale) and preserves the original distribution shape.

**Warnings:** - If all values are identical, standardization is impossible - Sensitive to outliers (they define the range)

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Rescale to [0, 1]
x <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)
result <- standardize_range(x)
result$standardized  # c(0, 0.167, 0.333, ..., 1)

# Rescale to [1, 7] (convert 1-5 scale to 1-7 scale)
x_5pt <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
result <- standardize_range(x_5pt, new_min = 1, new_max = 7)
result$standardized  # c(1, 2.5, 4, 5.5, 7)

# Rescale to [0, 100]
x <- c(10, 20, 30, 40, 50)
result <- standardize_range(x, new_min = 0, new_max = 100)
result$standardized  # c(0, 25, 50, 75, 100)
} # }
